t: Proverbs 23
When*pn you sit down to eat with a ruler, observe*ld carefully what is before you,
and*ln put a knife to your throat if*ld you are given to appetite.
Do*ln not desire his delicacies, for*ld they are deceptive food.
Do*ln not toil to acquire wealth; be*ld discerning enough to desist.
When*ln your eyes light on it, it is gone, for*ld suddenly it sprouts wings, flying*ld like an eagle toward heaven.
Do*ln not eat the bread of a man who is stingy; do*ld not desire his delicacies,
for*ln he is like one who is inwardly calculating. “Eat*ld and drink!” he says to you, but*ld his heart is not with you.
You*ln will vomit up the morsels that you have eaten, and*ld waste your pleasant words.
Do*ln not speak in the hearing of a fool, for*ld he will despise the good sense of your words.
Do*ln not move an ancient landmark or*ld enter the fields of the fatherless,
for*ln their Redeemer is strong; he*ld will plead their cause against you.
Apply*ln your heart to instruction and*ld your ear to words of knowledge.
Do*ln not withhold discipline from a child; if*ld you strike him with a rod, he will not die.
If*ln you strike him with the rod, you*ld will save his soul from Sheol.
My*ln son, if your heart is wise, my*ld heart too will be glad.
My*ln inmost being will exult when*ld your lips speak what is right.
Let*ln not your heart envy sinners, but*ld continue in the fear of the Lord*s all the day.
Surely*ln there is a future, and*ld your hope will not be cut off.
Hear,*pn my son, and be wise, and*ld direct your heart in the way.
Be*ln not among drunkards or*ld among gluttonous eaters of meat,
for*ln the drunkard and the glutton will come to poverty, and*ld slumber will clothe them with rags.
Listen*pn to your father who gave you life, and*ld do not despise your mother when she is old.
Buy*ln truth, and do not sell it; buy*ld wisdom, instruction, and understanding.
The*ln father of the righteous will greatly rejoice; he*ld who fathers a wise son will be glad in him.
Let*ln your father and mother be glad; let*ld her who bore you rejoice.
My*pn son, give me your heart, and*ld let your eyes observe my ways.
For*ln a prostitute is a deep pit; an*ld adulteress is a narrow well.
She*ln lies in wait like a robber and*ld increases the traitors among mankind.
Who*pn has woe? Who has sorrow? Who*ld has strife? Who has complaining? Who*ln has wounds without cause? Who*ld has redness of eyes?
Those*ln who tarry long over wine; those*ld who go to try mixed wine.
Do*ln not look at wine when it is red, when*ld it sparkles in the cup and*ld goes down smoothly.
In*ln the end it bites like a serpent and*ld stings like an adder.
Your*ln eyes will see strange things, and*ld your heart utter perverse things.
You*ln will be like one who lies down in the midst of the sea, like*ld one who lies on the top of a mast.
“They*ln struck me,” you will say, “but I was not hurt; they*ld beat me, but I did not feel it. When*ln shall I awake? I*ld must have another drink.”
